docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called yesterday for an end to automatic pay raises for unionized city workers, from trash collectors to teachers, and proposed $2 billion in tax cuts over the next four years to residents and businesses as part of a $36.8 billion budget he released. The spending plan for the 2001 fiscal year, perhaps the last for the mayor, who is an undeclared candidate for the United States Senate, is balanced in part by relying on an expected record surplus generated in the current fiscal year by the city's supercharged economy.

headline.main: Tax Cuts and Merit Pay System Are at Heart of Giuliani Budget

docs.abstract: New York City Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani calls for an end to automatic pay raises for unionized city workers, from trash collectors to teachers, and proposes $2 billion in tax cuts over the next four years to residents and businesses as part of $36.8 billion budget he releases; spending plan for 2001 fiscal year is balanced in part by relying on an expected record surplus in current fiscal year by city's supercharged economy; Giuliani devotes large portion of his budget speech to city's public schools, insisting again that school system is out of control and its management bloated; Giuliani repeatedly praises his management of city while complaining about financial disasters he says were caused by his Democratic predecessors; announces his intention to ask State Legislature for authority to borrow billions of dollars more to build new schools, courthouses and even a West Side sports complex; proposes cut in city's income tax rate for all New Yorkers that would average 16 percent; highlights of Mayor's plan reviewed; photo; pie chart shows budget allocations (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In proposing tonight to reduce the marriage penalty that the tax code levies on many two-income couples, President Clinton embraced an issue that has been pushed for years by Republicans and so opened the door to a compromise on an election-year tax cut. The approach set out by Mr. Clinton would help fewer couples than alternative changes preferred by most Republicans, and in particular would do little for couples in higher income brackets.

headline.main: Marriage-Penalty Proposal Could Ease Way to Tax Cut
headline.kicker: THE STATE OF THE UNION: WIDE-RANGING IDEAS

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican leaders in the State Senate proposed today that the state pick up all costs incurred by local governments, including New York City, to provide coverage for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who do not have medical insurance. The move by the Republican leaders puts them at odds with their chief ally in the Capitol, Gov. George E. Pataki, who has argued that the state should not foot the entire bill for providing medical coverage to low-income people.

headline.main: G.O.P. Plan Has State Pay For Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: With one eye on his own legacy and another on the political aspirations of his vice president, President Clinton claimed credit tonight for leading the nation onto the broad uplands of unparalleled prosperity and laid out an election-year manifesto for his party. Inevitably, he spoke of successfully crossing his bridge to the 21st century. Inevitably, he spoke at great length. Inevitably, he put some Democratic spots on Republican ideas. Inevitably, too, he set sweeping goals -- no child raised in poverty, affordable health care for everyone, a cleaner and safer planet -- without providing much of a road map toward realizing them.

headline.kicker: THE STATE OF THE UNION: NEWS ANALYSIS

docs.abstract: R W Apple analysis of Pres Clinton's State of Union address; observes that Clinton spoke with all the expansiveness of a man who hit the lottery, as he claims credit for leading nation onto broad uplands of unparalleled prosperity and laid out election-year manifesto for his party; notes he set sweeping goals--no child raised in poverty, affordable health care for everyone, a cleaner and safer planet--without providing much of a road map toward realizing them (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton proposed an ambitious, multifaceted health care agenda tonight, calling on Congress to provide prescription drugs to the elderly, new government subsidies to help people buy health insurance, new tax breaks for long-term care and a new federal law to define the rights of people in health maintenance organizations. In his State of the Union address, the president urged Congress to ''give every senior a voluntary choice of affordable coverage for prescription drugs.'' But contrary to expectations, he did not dwell on this proposal, and he did not accuse drug companies of charging excessive prices, as he often has in the past.

headline.main: Far-Reaching Plan Offered On Drugs and the Uninsured
headline.kicker: THE STATE OF THE UNION: HEALTH

docs.lead_paragraph: Snow paralyzes some American cities and disheartens others. But Minneapolis and its unidentical twin, St. Paul, cope with it. More than that; many people here positively revel in it. Winter is their favorite season. Come here the morning after a blizzard, and main roads have already been cleared. One time my wife, Betsey, and I, inured to snow-induced civic inertia in Washington, watched dumbfounded as a miniature street-sweeping machine brushed snow from downtown sidewalks as soon as it fell.

headline.main: Where Winter's a Wonder and Smiles Are Sincere. You Betcha.

docs.abstract: R W Apple Jr On the Road article on wintertime visit to Minneapolis and St Paul, where inhabitants positively revel in snow, and midday temperatures often struggle to reach balmy double digits; suggests indoor diversions, including art museums; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Israel's Governing Party Faces Finance Inquiry Israel's state comptroller, Eliezer Goldberg, left, fined Prime Minister Ehud Barak's One Israel party and put it under criminal investigation after issuing an account of what he called violations of campaign finance laws during the 1999 election. Mr. Barak was not personally implicated, and there was no immediate political threat to him. A1 Berlin Holocaust Memorial Site A site beside the Brandenburg Gate was dedicated for a Holocaust memorial, ending a decade of debate over how Germany should commemorate the Holocaust in its capital. docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore continued his drumbeat against former Senator Bill Bradley today, accusing him of using negative attacks. The Gore campaign seemed stung at Wednesday night's debate when Mr. Bradley accused Mr. Gore of lying and of distorting Mr. Bradley's record. The Gore camp was fighting assertions not only by Mr. Bradley but also by the debate moderator that Mr. Gore has been distorting Mr. Bradley's record and his health-care proposal. During the debate, Mr. Bradley compared Mr. Gore to former President Richard M. Nixon, the emblem of dishonesty in high office.

headline.main: Gore Hammers Bradley As Using Negative Attack

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore continues his harsh criticisms of former Sen Bill Bradley, accusing him of using negative attacks; photo (M)
